2 things: the user file may or may not be root, and the kubelet file is actually /var/lib/kubelet/config.json

And note that the linter would prefer that you use the file module for this rather than running the ln command.

I think you can combine these with:

"~{{ buildset_registry_docker_user | default(ansible_user) }}/.docker/config.json"

nova/compute/resource_tracker.py.message: do we really want a dict in the middle of this message?

I didn't come up with a better way to re-format the message off the top of my head when I pushed this up. Maybe something like:

"Instance %s has been scheduled to this compute host, the scheduler has made an allocation against this compute node but the instance has yet to start. Allocations: %s"

?

I also thought about moving instance=instance for logging instead of putting the instance uuid in the message as a substitution variable but that would be unrelated. Same for logging the compute node / resource provider uuid in the message for context.

Unrelated, but this shows up a lot in CI runs:

http://logstash.openstack.org/#dashboard/file/logstash.json?query=message%3A%5C%22is%20not%20being%20actively%20managed%20by%5C%22%20AND%20tags%3A%5C%22screen-n-cpu.txt%5C%22&from=7d

Which indicates it's normal and shouldn't be a warning. Likely racing with some migration operation.

Actually digging into one of these shows it's hitting this while unshelving an instance. During unshelve we call instance_claim which will set the instance.host and instance.node values:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/619c0c676aae5359225c54bc27ce349e138e420e/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L208

before eventually adding the instance to the tracked_instances dict:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/619c0c676aae5359225c54bc27ce349e138e420e/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L217

If update_available_resource periodic runs between those times we'll get this warning. So this should probably not be a warning if the instance task_state is set (because the instance is undergoing some state transition). Arguably we don't really need to log this (or make it debug) if we know the instance is being unshelved (task_state=spawning and shelved_at is in instance.system_metadata - but maybe that's going a bit too far).

Anyway, that's a separate bug.
Does this reference to 'heal' also no longer make sense?

Maybe...if it does make sense then that means my change doesn't really make sense, and if we consider 'healing allocations' just not deleting them for deleted instances - rather than what I'm thinking 'healing' means, which was the old stuff the RT used to do as noted in the commit message, then I could just abandon this change.

web/src/containers/build/Manifest.jsx.message: Need "var log_prefix" here to define the variable.
And if you have no initial value, as in this case, let x = null ?

Using let instead of var is better, although this is working code, so I'm fine with it.

The scoping rules between the two are different - it doesn't matter in this patch, but in general var is WEIRD so it's good to develop a habit of using let instead.

(tl;dr - if you do:

 console.log(x)
 var x = 5

The console log will print "undefined" because for strange reasons javascript decides to scope var x to the entire surrounding block.

let works like we expect variables to work from python:

  console.log(x)
  let x = 5

results in an error of x not being defined - because x isn't defined until it is when you use let.

Same thing - the console.log is still an error, because x hasn't been defined yet. You can even do:

  console.log(x)
  let x

and the first line will be an error.

(incidentally, you can put those lines in a foo.js file and run "node foo.js" on the CLI and it'll demonstrate the behavior differences)

specs/approved/armada_manifest_and_valid.message: Have we identified any validations that we would want to make optional as opposed to required, in order to make this refactoring effort and extra API surface worthwhile?
POPOs (python classes) would be an option as well, as they tend to provide more structure.

The model objects would represent the armada chart specs, and likely chart groups and manifest as well, after applying overrides, validation, other configuration.  Some of the fields would need to be more dynamic via dicts e.g. fields which hold k8s labels, but at least at the top-level they should be static enough for classes.

Assigning appropriate default values to fields, rather than null (`None`) should help with accessing longer property chains e.g. `a.b.c.d` which I think is one of the things Marshall was looking at `Box` for.
Would the model need to reflect dynamic structures (like values overrides) that would be a better fit for dictionaries than classes?

recently I tried to have opensuse tumbleweed just as a caching proxy instead of a full mirror. would this scheme still allow selecting something else for a particular distribution version?
This example doesn't match the docs.

This should either be "pypi_wheel" (with an underscore) or "wheel".

Also, does it make sense to have a wheel mirror without a pypi mirror?  If so, then that's enough.  But if not, we should make this a sub-key of pypi i think.

You might have a wheel mirror for your current platform/arch/etc that builds wheels for things that don't have wheels on pypi. In that case it would be a "mirror" of data but not of data on pypi.

Given that I think just "wheel" or "python_wheel" are good key names.

Let's say that somehow this dockerhub mirror required auth.  We could extend this like:
     dockerhub:
       url: https://{{ zuul_site_local_mirror_host }}:8082/
       username: foo
       password: bar
Or if we wanted to add general http proxy info here:
     http_proxy:
       url: ...
       username: ...
       password: ...
etc.

I think if/when we get to the point where we need to implement that in a role, we can update the documentation here to include any additional attributes we need.  Note that putting auth info in the site variable will expose it to all jobs, so that warrants caution.  However, this variable structure could come from a secret or some other source.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/api/controll.message:
question: so we're basically making a "magic" system override of "enabled" that is actually an attribute?

If we're doing that, why not just let people modify it via the existing user overrides mechanisms?

This is not a chart override. This is independent of the system generated overrides requested from the plugins (and saved in yaml files) and the user overrides (which need to be stored in the DB for merging). This attribute is saved in the mis-named system_overrides column of the table that we are using for saving persistent data for the helm plugins (passwords and ssh keys). Since I don't want that security information passed back, I'm filtering on user modifiable/presentable attributes. Currently this is an 'enabled' attribute that will be used to drive if a chart is kept/removed from the manifest.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/helm/manifes.message: should this have the @abc.abstractmethod decorator?  If not, then why do we need abc at all?

I'm following the same pattern established for the puppet/helm base classes. This is the base class for both the OpenstackArmadaManifestOperator and the PlatformArmadaManifestOperator classes BUT it is also called for 'generic' applications. 

By adding the @abc.abstractmethod stevedore extension loading complained. So I have now also added a GenericArmadaManifestOperator. 

Code updated accordingly for this.
where is this used?  (same for CHARTS_LUT)

The manifest operator has the knowledge of what the chart name/chart group name is for the chart plugin to use. It provides a single control point for naming that maps to the actual manifest entries. The LUTs are based on the chart name defined in the plugin. The manifest operator is passed to the plugin during overrides generation where, it can instruct the operator to perform insert/deletions based on it system configuration logic.

I think, the best approach would be to modify only the values we need to modify, which are the "container_images_file", "container_insecure_registries" (as mentioned in the previous comment, we'll need to do some conversion from the old release "docker_insecure_registries" and then assign the value we desire), the hieradata_override (I guess it should match with the name we have in the variable {{ undercloud_hiera }} and add the undercloud_enable_selinux to false (we should test manually if this is still needed).

placement/tests/functional/gabbits/granu.message: You might note here why this isn't working, as it is it simply looks like something you could uncomment and voila, the magic happens, which we established is sadly not true

How about this?

 $.allocation_requests[/allocations]..allocations['$ENVIRON["PF2_2_UUID"]'].resources.CUSTOM_VF: [2, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1]

where we sort it by the value of "allocations", which is a dict of resource-amount dict keyed by rp uuid, which is shorter when 2 VFs are come from the same provider.

This might be hacky enough to be well documented, but since this is tests, having it is better than nothing, isn't it?
Yeah, that's crazypants. And I like it. Will play.

It works, as Tetsuro suggests here, and as follows:

 In [2]: d1 = {'aaa': 1, 'bbb': 2}

 In [3]: d2 = {'zzz': 99}

 In [4]: d1 > d2
 Out[4]: True

But where is it documented that a smaller dict sorts smaller? That doesn't seem to work for any other data type:

 In [1]: [99,99] < [1,1,1]
 Out[1]: False

 In [6]: s1 = {1, 2}

 In [7]: s2 = {99}

 In [8]: s1 > s2
 Out[8]: False

 In [9]: 'aaa' > 'zz'
 Out[9]: False

I would especially have expected sets to follow the same behavior as dicts.

> But where is it documented that a smaller dict sorts smaller?

This, for example, seems wrong (unless I'm misunderstanding the wording):

https://thomas-cokelaer.info/tutorials/python/dicts.html#comparison

It turns out the sorting doesn't work at all in py3:

 "TypeError: '<' not supported between instances of 'dict' and 'dict'"

Got it. Thank you for looking into it anyway.
Another idea I come up with is using filtering hack.

  $.allocation_requests[?(allocations.'$ENVIRON["PF2_2_UUID"]'.resources.CUSTOM_VF<=1)]..allocations['$ENVIRON["PF2_2_UUID"]'].resources.CUSTOM_VF: [1, 1, 1, 1]
  $.allocation_requests[?(allocations.'$ENVIRON["PF2_2_UUID"]'.resources.CUSTOM_VF>1)]..allocations['$ENVIRON["PF2_2_UUID"]'].resources.CUSTOM_VF: [2, 2]

Tell me if I'm getting overheated...

That's a clever idea, I  guess jsonpath will let you sort before a .. in a clause with a ..

I assume you tried it?
Did you mean 6 here? I couldn't get what you wanted to validate.
Yes, I have missed this. Thanks!

if what you really care about is == 1 would that work better? (if it even works)

and 2, below
Considered it, but I actually prefer this as it proves that there's no results outside of the expected range. (E.g. 3, which would be a bug, or 0, which would be a bigger bug :)

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/agent/manage.message: Why is this in the "Create the filesystems" if statement?
inventory completion, as per bug report noted, now requires the completion of the host_filesystems (which were recently added, and can no longer just rely on inventoried disks/pvs).

The bug report said this:
If we do not fix this properly with an explicit/deterministic flag then we will trip over this issue each time someone adds a new inventory collection step to the end of the system inventory agent's initial process loop.

keystone/common/sql/expand_repo/versions.message: Could we just use "remote_id" instead of remote_id_attribute as every parameter is a attribute for a db table.

No, it would not be correct to call it 'remote_id'. 'remote_id' would refer to the IdP's entity ID, like 'https://samltest.id/idp'. 'remote_id_attribute' is not that, rather it's the Apache header that is set by the SP module that indicates where keystone should *look for* the remote ID, for example 'Shib-Identity-Provider' or 'MELLON_IDP'. 'remote_id_attribute' also mirrors the keystone.conf option that this is replacing.

doc/source/developer/specs/kubernetes-op.message:
Shouldn't this be specified? Fwiw here is the spec i used for the zuul+nodepool allinone operator poc:
  https://github.com/TristanCacqueray/zuul-operator/blob/master/ansible/group_vars/all.yaml#L3-L24

Perhaps we should isolate connections and tenants information, here are some proposals:

  kind: Zuul
  spec:
    merger:
      min: 0
      max: 5
    executor:
      min: 1
      max: 5
    web:
      min: 1
      max: 1
    executor_environment_configmap_name: null
    

  kind: ZuulConnection
  spec:
    name: ...
    configmap_name: null

  kind ZuulTenant
  spec:
    name: ...
    source:
      ...

Then a ZuulConnection config map would be provided by the user like so:

  kind: ConfigMap
  data:
    conn_rsa: ...
    zuul.d/conn.conf: |
      [connection name]
      driver=gerrit
      host=...
      sshkey=/etc/zuul/conn_rsa
s/operator/operate/
Similarly for Nodepool, we may want to have a CR per top-level nodepool configloader objects, e.g. NodepoolLabel, NodepoolProvider

CRD spec are provided as extra-var and they will override any group_vars/roles-default, thus we only need to reference dependencies apiVersion/kind as vars to enable override.

However, supporting multiple dependency implementations may be too much work since the different operators may behave differently (e.g. the postgresql operator on operatorhub requires a "primarysecretname" object to create the zuul user while another one may need something else).

Thus I think we should pick one for RDMS and one for Zookeeper and stick with it. I had good success with: https://operatorhub.io/operator/alpha/postgres-operator.v3.5.0 and https://github.com/pravega/zookeeper-operator#install-the-operator )

Hard no on Postgres as "the one", and mostly no on MySQL being "the one". Given that every Zuul I've set up is/was MySQL based, and OpenDev is as well. I don't think it would serve our community to tell other people to run what we don't, even if Postgres is a fine choice).

That said, I agree that they probably won't be entirely compatible, but I'd hope they can have flags, and the database can simply be an optional plug-in and not a hard-dependency, so users can simply choose between 1 of 4 options: CRD'd (mysql|postgres), or manually configured (mysql|postgres).

Since we should not dither over this, what if we just start with "plug in your database details here" and just make clear that we don't help you set up the database?

I think we should support only DBURI and one and only one CRD that the zuul operator manages.

DBURI handles all versions of the world where the user has an alternate opinion about what should happen with databases.

Only-one-CRD allows "kubectl get-me-a-zuul" to be about as straightforward as docker-compose.

The reason I think we should also support the db is that by and large the db for zuul is not interesting or hard to deal with and is an implementation detail for the simple case.

FWIW, we're running our zuul with postgres. But we use an externally managed db.

So I'd be fine with three options: CRD (mysql|postgres) and DBURI

However if it's too much effort (I don't know how much it would be) I think we should standardize the CRD to one.

Looking at the operatorhub catalogue, FWIW there are only percona and vitess operators to setup mysql. Shouldn't we consider the rdms an implementation detail that the user doesn't need to know about?

Otherwise I'm fine with enabling the user to provide it's own dburi.
Supporting both mysql|postgres may complicate OLM dependencies declaration, not sure we can declare optional dependencies based on a CRD spec option...
See above. I disagree with this point, but if we had to pick one, we'd have to pick the one that most current users are on, which I believe is MySQL. Also, a nit, it's either Postgres, or PostgreSQL.
Assuming we decide to support one, I agree that we should pick MySQL.

If the user can provides part of the zuul.conf, shouldn't we be able to discover if we need to setup a Zookeeper or a RDMS?

On the other hand, extra files may be needed by zuul.conf entries (such as ssh key for gerrit connection or github app certificats). Thus it may be worthy to consider providing a:

  apiVersion: zuul-ci.org/v1alpha1
  kind: Source
  spec:
    zuul_conf_entry_configmapname: ""
    secretname: ""

And iterate over those when creating the final zuul.conf and mount all the secrets in /var/lib/zuul

It would be nice if zuul did .d configuration, so we can just generate some in the Operator, and bind mount in others from secrets objects. I also submitted a patch a bazillion years ago (4 months?) that would allow environment variable interpolation in zuul.conf.. that would also help here.

++ for .d configuration

FTR, the environment interpolation change is here: https://review.opendev.org/612824

To keep things simple, we would also need to enable settings secrets content (e.g. ssh key) inline in the zuul conf (.d) so that the user can provide a single blob to describe a connection.

But since the operator is going to compose the configuration (at least to setup the zookeeper info), then it's not too much work to also append user provided sections.
+1 for zuul.d zuul.conf, I personally don't want to get into templating zuul.conf, I much rather patch static files when possible.

Deployment may not be able to detect config map change, thus we may need some extra CRD to manage the service lifecycle. For example, kind such as "ZuulReload" and "ZuulBackup" (to archive all the scheduler secrets, to be used by a companion "ZuulRestore")
Re graceful, yes, we should have that.  We did have it in v2.5, it just didn't make the initial v3 implementation: https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/executor/server.py#L2479
Yes please. To me the ability to programattically encode operations in to the deployment is the main reason to do this as an operator and not just ansible/helm/etc.

That process should be part of the regular deployment role, and we need to do that in many situations, e.g. if a connection is added or if the scheduler deployment changed. Here is how i prototyped this in: https://github.com/TristanCacqueray/zuul-operator/blob/master/ansible/roles/deploy/tasks/main.yaml#L8

For executor/merger, it would be nice to have a gracefull stop signal we could use as a preStop container hook (e.g. finish the current jobs and kill yourself when you are done).
Do we also want to specify some lifecycles (like upgrades) already or will this just be an implementation detail?

IIUC, upgrades are managed by the OLM itself (through the release of subsequent operator version). Otherwise, we could have a version field in the Zuul or Nodepool CRD to force using a specific image, but that shouldn't require an Upgrade CRD per se.

I mean the process of updating zuul itself. Like pausing executors before updating them or take a queue dump and re-enqueue on scheduler upgrade. These are the things that make an operator superior to helm/templates/..

We're working on approaching a point where the default logging for Zuul is what we would expect people to use, so perhaps here we should support three things: 1) by default, perform no logging config and Zuul uses its default (info level).  2) have a Zuul crd option to set debug logging option in the app crd. 3) allow the user to specify the full logging config as a configmap.
The operator is more than create, what about saying "create and update" or "manage", "operate"?
Good point.
nit: Extra whitespace
Done
Or we could take a page from the Rook design, and only support one Zuul in a namespace, then every ZuulConnection is automatically for that Zuul.

I like this better than the previous `ZuulConnection` proposal. 

The fewer resources there are, the easier it'll be to manage and reason about a Zuul deployment. It's true that a downside of this is that then the Zuul resource is going to be more complex to read but this information is relevant enough to have it set explicitly in the resource.

Also, the isolation here makes scaling zuul easier in a shared environment.
You don't need a launcher count because of the automatic sharding.
Oh - good point!

If we implement multi-node jobs across regions, we're really implementing them across pools, and right now we don't have a way for Nodepool to handle that, so it's hard to say whether this would prohibit that or not.  My guess is that this won't prevent that, since to handle that will almost certainly involve some kind of multi-process coordination.

As for sharding per-pool -- you're right, that's actually the smallest unit we can shard, so maybe we should do that.
Wouldn't that prevent using multi-nodes job across multiple region (if/when that's implemented)? Why not sharding per pool?

My only real concern, is for each new setting we add into zuul.conf, we also need to update the spec, is that right?

This is something I didn't like how we handled puppet modules, as each time we added a new setting, we also needed to go through 4 levels to add it.

Where, with a static file, we can just make the change in one place and not remember how the template of the template works.

If not, my comment can be ignored :)

No - I think we should be able to do direct passthrough. (let the operator yaml specify an arbitrary unspecified dict for each thing) ... then we only need to update the operator when we add new options that are secrets ... but we'll probably want to be making a patch to the operator in those cases to exercise such a new feature anyway.

ironic/common/neutron.py.message: So crazy idea. Why not change the access pattern as the purpose of the helper is to verify the security groups. Enumerate through the list of groups. Individually ask neutron about each one. That WILL take loner because we keep asking it for updates, but for a longer list being returned from the API it is no longer a database scan and ship of the data to the conductor to parse/process. We would hit neutron's API in rapid succession for index based queries. It would definitely slow down if someone had a long list of security groups to apply to their provisioning/cleaning networks... but we wouldn't be trying to sort through everything neutron is aware of.
I guess since `id` query does work, we don't need this?

If we wanted a traceback, couldn't we do something like this?

try:
    raise exception.MaxRetriesExceeded(reason=msg)
except exception.MaxRetriesExceeded as exc:
    with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception():
        self._cleanup_when_reschedule_fails(
            context, instance, exc, legacy_request_spec,
            requested_networks)

The save_and_reraise would make it raise the exception after cleanup, which we don't actually want.

But otherwise, yeah, this is substantially what was in PS3 where I thought it looked a bit weird to raise an exception just to immediately trap it purely for the purpose of passing it to the cleanup method.

Oh, I made a change to that method so that performs the check internally.  I did that because otherwise it's hard to chain these together like this.  I wanted it to be so that we would fetch the build if needed, then fetch the manifest if needed, then fetch the logfile if needed.  So we can just call all three of these, and they will check internally (we pass the force parameter in too).  They return a promise which is fulfilled immediately if nothing needs to be done, so that this moves on to the next step.

This is all because if you hit the build page first, you'll get the build info, then the manifest and job output.  So if you then go to the log viewer page, you only need to fetch the logfile. But if someone sends you a deep link to a log viewer, you'll get the build info, the manifest and logfile.  Then if you go back to the build page, you only need to fetch the build output.

web/src/reducers/logfile.js.message: I thought about that, but some of the logfiles are going to be huge, so I thought we should store only one at a time, otherwise if you browse several, we might use all the ram.

We might want to structure the logfile store using a map[url, data] so that we cache already fetched results.

This could also be used by the build.output which already cache the job-output.json.

I think there are middleware to deal with that. Or when reducing, we could manually walk the store and delete old & heavy log files.

Having the files in the store would help if we want to display the file content inlined in the tree view. Though that could be improved in a followup.

It should be fine to store, for example, a 50MB file in the redux store, what really slows down the browser is when it has to render that file. Thus I think we could limit the maximum size of the map, and perhaps force very large file to be opened in a new tab. e.g. a max size of 200MB should give plenty of room to cache most build's logs.

In any case, we could implement a client side filter logic to reduce the amount of text rendering. In that situation, I don't think we should worry about ringbuffer, unless the user click a >GB log file.

There's definitely a tradeoff here. Caching multiple files could be nice for switching around. However, for the large files streaming the contents and only storing what the user is actually looking at in ram is also potentially friendlier.

Maybe a ringbuffer that holds anything we actually completely fetched, ditching older ones? But dont' store them if we only partially streamed a result?

Sorry, I'm not quite buying this.

In all cases I can think of, there can be more than one subtree. E.g. for neutron, the sub-root is the NIC / physical port / PF, right? And that will be a direct descendant of the compute RP or NUMA node RP (both "owned" by the compute).

Ditto e.g. devices under cyborg.

Doing multiple "subtree" calls is going to be more expensive than client-side filtering from a single in_tree call pretty much every time.

I'm also totally not concerned about being able to "see" providers I don't "own". In fact, I see it as a necessary and healthy artifact of multiple agents being able to manage a single provider tree collaboratively.

You've got three calls (one from each agent) regardless; it's just a matter of whether the filtering is happening on the server or client side. We're talking about a very small number of providers (irl, a single provider tree might have what, 10 nodes at most? 20?) so it's not like we're taking a big hit on the payload processing/transmittal.

You can see the current neutron model at L82 below. There are three neturon agent subtrees belonging to three different neturon agents. Every neutron subtree has its own neutron agent RP as the root of that subtree. Each neutron agent wants to handle its own subtree independently from each others and independently the nova owned part of the tree.

This also means that those multiple subtree calls you mention will happen in independent neutron agents. Therefore using an in_tree call instead would mean 3 in_tree calls (on in each agent) and 3 client side filtering (on in each agent).

It will be driver-specific.

But the crux will be that each driver will receive the necessary information via the `allocations` parameter to e.g. the spawn ComputeDriver method. The driver will need to look for allocations of devices (presumably based on recognizing the namespaced prefix of the name of the resource provider associated with the allocation) and do whatever platform-specific thing is necessary to attach the device, just like they would have in the old world.

In libvirt, this is probably the guts of _guest_add_pci_devices.

The in-tree PowerVM driver doesn't support device passthrough yet, but we do it by stuffing the IOSlot object into the LogicalPartition object and sending that object to our REST API.

For drivers which already support passthrough, there will be a (multi-release) transition period where devices must be recognized through the legacy subsystem as well as the new placement-based system - i.e. the union of both should be funneled into whatever core attach/detach method does the real work. With appropriate error handling for conflicts between the two. (The dual-support thing is necessary so we can start with a subset of support in the new system - i.e. whole-device only as this spec says - and incrementally add other bits until everything is covered and we can deprecate/remove the legacy system entirely.)

I don't see how we can do one without the other. SR-IOV VF support is managed with the PCI manager and, while you say running the two side-by-side would be possible, I find it hard to see how that would be wise. What are the blocks that prevent us from tackling VFS in placement at the same time? I mean, they're essentially the same thing from an indexing perspective, right?
VGPU is already a distinct resource class that is currently handles by both the libvirt and Xen virt drivers.

A couple answers here.

I don't see it being possible for us to transition 100% in one spec/series/release. I could be wrong.

As you can see by the legacy PCI code, SR-IOV is a pretty complicated thing, with the ability to pass PFs vs VFs, direct vs macvtap (whatever that is), three different vif types... Also, the way VFs are managed is wildly different in PowerVM than in libvirt. (I therefore assume it might be wildly different for other platforms as well.) Trying to "solve" it in a generic way is going to be nontrivial. Certainly compared to passing through entire devices.
So if we want to bite off a chunk, SR-IOV seems like a fairly decent thing to leave behind for now.

Further on the topic of subsetting, IMO it also makes sense to draw a boundary at "devices with a wire out the back". Because that brings in questions of connectivity etc. which will be more complicated to solve than just "slap on a trait with the network name". There's interaction with neutron to consider, creating a port via a separate command, etc. We have to worry about none of that if we pass through whole devices via flavors.

As far as coexistence is concerned, it really shouldn't be a huge problem. I assume that operators can continue using [pci]passthrough_whitelist until we actually start removing that code, which presumably shouldn't be until we can do everything via placement. In the meantime, we'll gradually add support for things via the inventory.yaml and placement resource extra_specs, and anything the operator wants to do the new way they'll just use the new syntax for.

-1 for a couple reasons...

The device may be the provider of multiple types of resources. Imagine, for example, that you have an SR-IOV NIC. That NIC might provide SRIOV_NET_VF resources or it might be used as a PF passthrough, in which case it would have a single inventory record of a total of 1 resource class representing that passthrough device (SRIOV_NET_PF? PCI_PASSTHROUGH? etc)

Similarly, the device itself might not actually have ANY inventory itself but simply acts as an intermediary child provider. Think here of a NUMA system, where each NUMA cell acts as a child provider to the root compute node provider and each NUMA cell provider has multiple SR-IOV PF child providers with their own inventory of SRIOV_NET_VF resources. The NUMA cells may not have any inventory records at all.

It's a question of scope here. This spec isn't talking about defining all the providers for this compute node. It's only talking about inventorying the devices available for passthrough to VMs. You can't pass through a NUMA node. Virtual functions like VFs or VGPUs are out of scope for now.

So whereas the structure may be extended in the future (your point above about versioning is well taken) to accomodate more of those things, for now we're saying one (physical) device == one provider with one inventory unit of one resource class.

I have no strong opinion on actually allowing drivers to generate custom traits. As I say, I envision it as a transitional mechanism, expecting that any driver-generated trait should be superseded by a standard one from os-traits (see 2nd paragraph).

I don't think there is a strong need for such a thing however, as this is part of driver code and therefore the future code reviews on the actual implementations should be responsible to enforce this.

For inter-cloud interoperability, the divergence of different drivers could indeed be problematic. However, isn't the ability of the operators to specify custom traits much more problematic on this account? But at the same time, it is necessary to have any sort of flexibility with local setups.

THIS. The responsibility for a) discovering which devices exist on the system; b) parsing the inventory.yaml file; c) intersecting the two to produce a filtered list of allowed devices; and d) managing the placement artifacts (providers, inventories, traits, etc.) for those devices MUST BE ON THE VIRT DRIVER. I remember discussing this, but not agreeing on it.

The way I would like to see generated vs. specified traits handled is via namespacing. The generated traits have a reserved prefix that flags them as being "owned" by the device management code in the virt driver. The driver has the right to (and should) remove any traits with that prefix which are not in the set it detects. And the user is free to specify any traits outside of that namespace. No +/- necessary. And no mechanism to switch off the generated traits (why would you need to do that?).

Affinity use cases like "same network" are addressed by traits.

For affinity use cases like "same SAN switch port" are only helped by collating device inventories if the devices in question are truly identical in every other (interesting) way. Otherwise their trait sets will be non-overlapping and it's truly broken for them to be represented in the same inventory at all. More on this below.

For affinity use cases where we can't pool the inventories, we still have placement enablement work to do. We've discussed a couple of options here in the past, including using an intermediate child provider with a trait representing the type of grouping (but not the specific group - e.g. CUSTOM_SAN_PORT_GROUPING, not CUSTOM_SAN_PORT_4CF1) and a new option to GET /allocation_candidates like ?same_ancestor_by_trait=CUSTOM_SAN_PORT_GROUPING.

 > for HA

Right, this is a contentious point. We decided to do one-provider-per-device in PowerVM because we have actual use cases where customers want to be able to designate a specific device for their (pet) VM.

But also because, as kosamara implies, it makes it trivial (in fact unnecessary) to backtrace which *specific* device was plugged into your VM based on the placement data. Perhaps it's possible to think of different devices as being completely interchangeable, but, as kosamara says, you would have to do it based on the union of all the provider information, not just the resource class. And that is a lot harder to do.

AFAICT, assuming our nested resource provider code works as it should, there is no technical downside to doing one provider per resource. The only possible objections are "aesthetic" ones. (I'm sure someone will argue otherwise.)

It makes sense to me to follow the logic of merging inventories if the device traits are the same, because this leaves it up to the operator to annotate each device with a special trait if he cares to separate them.

OTOH, if there is a use case:

  - (anti-affinity) for requesting 2 SR-IOV VFs from different NICs for HA

But I think by stealing Sean's idea of device pools we can make this work. Why don't we just do it by adding a `device_pool: <name>` field to the rule paragraph? Same device_pool, same resource provider. Then we should come up with a namespacing scheme for the resource provider so that we can still detect and remove ones that have gone away. And if device_pool is omitted, we use a single provider per device.

I think there's still a danger here in that the operator could pool devices with conflicting generated traits. Perhaps that should be an error.

And it also means that specified traits would have to match - and thus be repeated - in all paragraphs for a single pool. Which sucks. So never mind, let's not do that.

[END]

But remind me why we care in the first place? Is the only reason a philosophical one, that placement is "supposed" to present identical resources in a single inventory?

If that's the only reason pro aggregation, then given how many reasons we have con, I say we don't do it, at least not yet. If we come up with a good reason - and a good non-awkward design - we can enhance in the future, cool?

(BTW, anti-affinity and/or QoS may be farfetched with VGPUs, but certainly not with e.g. SR-IOV VFs, which I hope will eventually be handled through this same mechanism.)

kernel same page merging is basically a copy on write optimization that enables grater oversubscription of memory by merging read only or infrequently written pages between multipel process to refer to a single phyical page in memory.

the stuttering that is observed happens when a merged page is modified by the running guest in which case it needs to actually be copied by the kernel which intoduces more latancy then updating a non merged page.
i would just make this "hw:kms" and make it trisate boolean that if not set does nothing. if set to true will force kms and if set to false will disable kms.

Libvirt does not have such functionality (to force ksm). https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html only "<nosharepages/>" to disable, and if not defined - determined by qemu, based on /etc/default/qemu-kvm and whether KSM was enabled in kernel config (afaik for major distros it is enabled).
ksm on/off might be somting we should add to the host as a trait in placement.

I really don't know that traits are so cannot elaborate on this. I was asked to create a spec and so I did, but my intention was only to add a simple flag to disable KSM, I'm not a specialist in Nova architecture.

traits are a set of capablities that we tag resouce providers in the placement api with do descibe the qualitaive aspects of a resouce.

so ssd would be a trait for a block device.
a cpu instruct set would be a trait for a processor.


so in this case i a suggsting that you would tag a host with and then schdule based on guest request. so to land on a host with kms disabeld you would set a fobinid trait of kms in the placement query which would be generated by setting hw:kms=off in the flavor extra spec.

That's actually not what the weigher does, though. All the soft-affinity weighers do is give hosts that contain members of the instance group a weight of 1.0 and hosts that don't have a member of the instance group in it a weight of 0.0. Yes, but that's not what comes back from the UDP Sender. It packages it up like this: http://paste.openstack.org/show/753761/
In that example, the "57ce7c8e" is actually the LB_ID. So, without changing the amphora side code, we really can't know the listener IDs. :(
And in fact, it's going to only ever give us the one, even though there will be multiple listeners in the file, because of how it's getting the data.

Uhh, so, pretty sure this is always going to break with more than one configured listener, because the thing that the health reports is based on the haproxy instance, which is now 1-per-amp. The ID of the "listener" is actually the lb_id. I tested this...
Why are you excluding UDP here? UDP should be in this health message for version 1 and newer agents. This would be a change from the previous functionality.

This should account for *ALL* listeners.
The part that is probably tricking you is there are now three heartbeat message versions, the first two handle UDP differently. There are different tests for the different formats. In a previous patch you changed the message version for some tests from "none/0" to "1", which changed the way UDP was handled and caused the tests to fail.  I reverted those changes.

The "expected listener count" is for things in the haproxy stats message, isn't it? Or is this *all* of them joined together I guess?
